g.text: We theoretically investigate the mechanism of ferroelectric switching via interlayer shear in 3R MoS
using first principles and lattice dynamics calculations. First principle calculations show the prominent
anharmonic coupling of the infrared inactive interlayer shear and the infrared active phonons. The
nonlinear coupling terms generates an effective anharmonic force which drives the interlayer shear
mode and lowers the ferroelectric switching barrier depending on the amplitude and polarization of
infrared mode. Lattice dynamics simulations show that the interlayer shear mode can be coherently
excited to the switching threshold by a train of infrared pulses polarized along the zigzag axis of MoS
The results of this study indicate the possibility of ultrafast ferroelectricity in stacked two-dimensional
materials from the control of stacking sequence.
Ferroelectric two-dimensional (2D) materials are of great importance in realizing non-volatile devices with
, and possibly with unforeseen functionalities from the unique properties of 2D materials
However, studies on the 2D ferroelectrics are yet an emerging field. Only a few materials such as SnTe
have been experimentally shown to work in agreement with theories
is another major 2D materials class showing versatile electronic phases ranging from semiconducting or metallic
phase to that with topological characteristics
. Nonetheless, the ferroelectricity of the TMDC is very scarce due
to the underlying symmetry of single layer in stable phase, which is either non-polar or centrosymmetric, pre-
showed ferroelectric instability of single layer 1T MoS
, its realization in the experiment is challenging because
is stable in semiconducting 2H phase rather than metallic 1T structure
The ferroelectricity is likely to appear in stacked TMDC rather than in single layer form. It was recently shown
that the horizontal mirror symmetry of individual layers is broken by the stacking in 3R structure (
for bulk), hence the vertical electric polarization manifests itself in accordance with the
. The direction of polarization depends on the stacking sequence, hence is reversed by
the interlayer translation between the AB and AC stackings
tric switching in the 3R structure via the interlayer translation has not been explored to date. Meanwhile, the
experiments, probably via the interlayer translation. The stability of the 3R structure MoS
of the 2H structure and can be selectively synthesized among competing polytypes
. It is hence a viable candidate
for 2D ferroelectrics in which the fascinating phenomena such as high electron mobility
The interlayer translation universally manifests as Raman active low-frequency lattice vibrations in layered
2D crystals due to the weak van der Waals bonds (vdW) between layers
using an optical field based on ionic Raman scattering is considerably appealing
called nonlinear phononics, relies on the anharmonic phonon coupling between infrared active and targeted
secondary vibrational modes, which displaces the crystal toward the reversal of polarization upon the irradi-
. The ionic Raman scattering is distinguished from the conventional Raman
scattering which has been used to detect structural characteristics of 2D materials such as stacking structures
. The use of pulse with the mid-infrared frequency within short duration allows the
exploration of an extremely intense light field (peak electric field reaching ~600 MVcm
Center for Electronic Materials, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, Seoul, 02792, Korea.
